translation_text.dn2:4.2: “Sire, Ajita of the hair blanket leads an order and a community, and tutors a community. He’s a well-known and famous religious founder, deemed holy by many people. He is of long standing, long gone forth; he is advanced in years and has reached the final stage of life.
translation_text.dn2:4.3: Let Your Majesty pay homage to him.
translation_text.dn2:4.4: Hopefully in so doing your mind will find peace.”
translation_text.dn2:4.5: But when he had spoken, the king kept silent.
translation_text.dn2:5.1: Another of the king’s ministers said to him,
translation_text.dn2:5.2: “Sire, Pakudha Kaccāyana leads an order and a community, and tutors a community. He’s a well-known and famous religious founder, deemed holy by many people. He is of long standing, long gone forth; he is advanced in years and has reached the final stage of life.
translation_text.dn2:5.3: Let Your Majesty pay homage to him.
translation_text.dn2:5.4: Hopefully in so doing your mind will find peace.”
translation_text.dn2:5.5: But when he had spoken, the king kept silent.
translation_text.dn2:6.1: Another of the king’s ministers said to him,
translation_text.dn2:6.2: “Sire, Sañjaya Belaṭṭhiputta leads an order and a community, and tutors a community. He’s a well-known and famous religious founder, deemed holy by many people. He is of long standing, long gone forth; he is advanced in years and has reached the final stage of life.
translation_text.dn2:6.3: Let Your Majesty pay homage to him.
translation_text.dn2:6.4: Hopefully in so doing your mind will find peace.”
translation_text.dn2:6.5: But when he had spoken, the king kept silent.
translation_text.dn2:7.1: Another of the king’s ministers said to him,
translation_text.dn2:7.2: “Sire, the Jain ascetic of the Ñātika clan leads an order and a community, and tutors a community. He’s a well-known and famous religious founder, deemed holy by many people. He is of long standing, long gone forth; he is advanced in years and has reached the final stage of life.
translation_text.dn2:7.3: Let Your Majesty pay homage to him.
translation_text.dn2:7.4: Hopefully in so doing your mind will find peace.”
translation_text.dn2:7.5: But when he had spoken, the king kept silent.
translation_text.dn2:8.1: Now at that time Jīvaka Komārabhacca was sitting silently not far from the king.
translation_text.dn2:8.2: Then the king said to him,
translation_text.dn2:8.3: “But my dear Jīvaka, why are you silent?”
translation_text.dn2:8.4: “Sire, the Blessed One, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha is staying in my mango grove together with a large Saṅgha of 1,250 mendicants.
translation_text.dn2:8.6: ‘That Blessed One is perfected, a fully awakened Buddha, accomplished in knowledge and conduct, holy, knower of the world, supreme guide for those fit for training, teacher of gods and humans, awakened, blessed.’
translation_text.dn2:8.7: Let Your Majesty pay homage to him.
translation_text.dn2:8.8: Hopefully in so doing your mind will find peace.”
translation_text.dn2:8.9: “Well then, my dear Jīvaka, have the elephants readied.”
translation_text.dn2:9.1: “Yes, Your Majesty,” replied Jīvaka. He had around five hundred female elephants readied, in addition to the king’s bull elephant for riding. Then he informed the king,
translation_text.dn2:10.1: Then King Ajātasattu had women mounted on each of the five hundred female elephants, while he mounted his bull elephant. With attendants carrying torches, he set out in full royal pomp from Rājagaha to Jīvaka’s mango grove.
translation_text.dn2:10.2: But as he drew near the mango grove, the king became frightened, scared, his hair standing on end.
translation_text.dn2:10.4: “My dear Jīvaka, I hope you’re not deceiving me!
translation_text.dn2:10.5: I hope you’re not betraying me!
translation_text.dn2:10.6: I hope you’re not turning me over to my enemies!
translation_text.dn2:10.7: For how on earth can there be no sound of coughing or clearing throats or any noise in such a large Saṅgha of 1,250 mendicants?”
translation_text.dn2:10.8: “Do not fear, great king, do not fear!
translation_text.dn2:10.11: or turning you over to your enemies.
translation_text.dn2:10.12: Go forward, great king, go forward! Those are lamps shining in the pavilion.”
translation_text.dn2:11.0: 3. The Question About the Fruits of the Ascetic Life
translation_text.dn2:11.1: Then King Ajātasattu rode on the elephant as far as the terrain allowed, then descended and approached the pavilion door on foot, where he asked Jīvaka,
translation_text.dn2:11.2: “But my dear Jīvaka, where is the Buddha?”
translation_text.dn2:11.3: “That is the Buddha, great king, that is the Buddha!
translation_text.dn2:11.4: He’s sitting against the central column facing east, in front of the Saṅgha of mendicants.”
translation_text.dn2:12.1: Then the king went up to the Buddha and stood to one side.
translation_text.dn2:12.2: He looked around the Saṅgha of mendicants, who were so very silent, like a still, clear lake, and expressed this heartfelt sentiment,
translation_text.dn2:12.3: “May my son, Prince Udāyibhadda, be blessed with such peace as the Saṅgha of mendicants now enjoys!”
translation_text.dn2:12.4: “Has your mind gone to one you love, great king?”
translation_text.dn2:12.5: “I love my son, sir, Prince Udāyibhadda.
translation_text.dn2:12.6: May he be blessed with such peace as the Saṅgha of mendicants now enjoys!”
translation_text.dn2:13.1: Then the king bowed to the Buddha, raised his joined palms toward the Saṅgha, and sat down to one side.
translation_text.dn2:13.3: “Sir, I’d like to ask you about a certain point, if you’d take the time to answer.”
translation_text.dn2:14.1: “Sir, there are many different professional fields.
translation_text.dn2:14.2: These include elephant riders, cavalry, charioteers, archers, bannermen, adjutants, food servers, warrior-chiefs, princes, chargers, great warriors, heroes, leather-clad soldiers, and sons of bondservants.
translation_text.dn2:14.3: They also include bakers, barbers, bathroom attendants, cooks, garland-makers, dyers, embroiderers, basket-makers, potters, accountants, finger-talliers, or those following any similar professions. All these live off the fruits of their profession which are apparent in this very life.
translation_text.dn2:14.4: With that they make themselves happy and pleased. They make their parents, their children and partners, and their friends and colleagues happy and pleased. And they establish an uplifting religious donation for ascetics and brahmins that’s conducive to heaven, ripens in happiness, and leads to heaven.
translation_text.dn2:14.5: Sir, can you point out a fruit of the ascetic life that’s likewise apparent in this very life?”
translation_text.dn2:15.1: “Great king, do you recall having asked this question of other ascetics and brahmins?”
translation_text.dn2:15.3: “If you wouldn’t mind, great king, tell me how they answered.”
translation_text.dn2:15.4: “It’s no trouble when someone such as the Blessed One is sitting here.”
translation_text.dn2:16.1: “This one time, sir, I approached Pūraṇa Kassapa and exchanged greetings with him.
translation_text.dn2:16.2: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, I sat down to one side, and asked him the same question.
translation_text.dn2:17.2: ‘Great king, the one who acts does nothing wrong when they punish, mutilate, torture, aggrieve, oppress, intimidate, or when they encourage others to do the same. They do nothing wrong when they kill, steal, break into houses, plunder wealth, steal from isolated buildings, commit highway robbery, commit adultery, and lie. If you were to reduce all the living creatures of this earth to one heap and mass of flesh with a razor-edged chakram, no evil comes of that, and no outcome of evil.
translation_text.dn2:17.3: If you were to go along the south bank of the Ganges killing, mutilating, and torturing, and encouraging others to do the same, no evil comes of that, and no outcome of evil.
translation_text.dn2:17.4: If you were to go along the north bank of the Ganges giving and sacrificing and encouraging others to do the same, no merit comes of that, and no outcome of merit.
translation_text.dn2:17.5: In giving, self-control, restraint, and truthfulness there is no merit or outcome of merit.’
translation_text.dn2:18.1: And so, when I asked Pūraṇa Kassapa about the fruits of the ascetic life apparent in the present life, he answered with the doctrine of inaction.
translation_text.dn2:18.2: It was like someone who, when asked about a mango, answered with a breadfruit, or when asked about a breadfruit, answered with a mango.
translation_text.dn2:18.5: ‘How on earth could one such as I presume to rebuke an ascetic or brahmin living in my realm?’
translation_text.dn2:18.6: So I neither approved nor rejected that statement of Pūraṇa Kassapa.
translation_text.dn2:18.7: I was displeased, but did not express my displeasure. Neither accepting what he said nor contradicting it, I got up from my seat and left.
translation_text.dn2:19.0: 3.2. The Doctrine of the Bamboo-staffed Ascetic Gosāla
translation_text.dn2:19.1: This one time, sir, I approached the bamboo-staffed ascetic Gosāla and exchanged greetings with him.
translation_text.dn2:19.2: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, I sat down to one side, and asked him the same question.
translation_text.dn2:20.2: ‘Great king, there is no cause or reason for the corruption of sentient beings. Sentient beings are corrupted without cause or reason.
translation_text.dn2:20.3: There’s no cause or reason for the purification of sentient beings.
translation_text.dn2:20.4: Sentient beings are purified without cause or reason.
translation_text.dn2:20.5: One does not act of one’s own volition, one does not act of another’s volition, one does not act from a person’s volition. There is no power, no energy, no human strength or vigor.
translation_text.dn2:20.6: All sentient beings, all living creatures, all beings, all souls lack control, power, and energy. Molded by destiny, circumstance, and nature, they experience pleasure and pain in the six classes of rebirth.
translation_text.dn2:20.7: There are 1.4 million main wombs, and 6,000, and 600; 500 deeds, and five, and three; deeds and half-deeds; 62 paths of practice, 62 sub-eons, six classes of rebirth, and eight stages in a person’s life; 4,900 Ājīvaka ascetics, 4,900 wanderers, and 4,900 dragon abodes; 2,000 lordships, 3,000 hells, and 36 realms of dusky sky; seven percipient embryos, seven non-percipient embryos, seven knotless embryos, seven gods, seven mental heavens, seven goblins, seven streams, seven castoff incarnations and 700 castoff incarnations, seven downfalls and 700 downfalls, seven dreams and 700 dreams, and 8.4 million great eons—through all of which the foolish and the astute transmigrate before making an end of suffering.
translation_text.dn2:20.8: And here there is no such thing as this: “By this precept or observance or fervent austerity or spiritual life I shall force unripened deeds to bear their fruit, or eliminate old deeds by experiencing their results little by little,” for that cannot be.
translation_text.dn2:20.9: Pleasure and pain are allotted. Transmigration lasts only for a limited period, so there’s no increase or decrease, no getting better or worse.
translation_text.dn2:20.10: It’s like how, when you toss a ball of string, it rolls away unraveling.
translation_text.dn2:20.11: In the same way, after transmigrating the foolish and the astute will make an end of suffering.’
translation_text.dn2:21.1: And so, when I asked the bamboo-staffed ascetic Gosāla about the fruits of the ascetic life apparent in the present life, he answered with the doctrine of purification through transmigration.
translation_text.dn2:21.2: It was like someone who, when asked about a mango, answered with a breadfruit, or when asked about a breadfruit, answered with a mango.
translation_text.dn2:21.5: ‘How on earth could one such as I presume to rebuke an ascetic or brahmin living in my realm?’
translation_text.dn2:21.6: So I neither approved nor rejected that statement of the bamboo-staffed ascetic Gosāla.
translation_text.dn2:21.7: I was displeased, but did not express my displeasure. Neither accepting what he said nor contradicting it, I got up from my seat and left.
translation_text.dn2:22.0: 3.3. The Doctrine of Ajita of the Hair Blanket
translation_text.dn2:22.1: This one time, sir, I approached Ajita of the hair blanket and exchanged greetings with him.
translation_text.dn2:22.2: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, I sat down to one side, and asked him the same question.
translation_text.dn2:23.2: ‘Great king, there is no meaning in giving, sacrifice, or offerings. There’s no fruit or result of good and bad deeds. There’s no afterlife. There’s no such thing as mother and father, or beings that are reborn spontaneously. And there’s no ascetic or brahmin who is rightly comported and rightly practiced, and who describes the afterlife after realizing it with their own insight.
translation_text.dn2:23.3: This person is made up of the four principal states. When they die, the earth in their body merges and coalesces with the substance of earth. The water in their body merges and coalesces with the substance of water. The fire in their body merges and coalesces with the substance of fire. The air in their body merges and coalesces with the substance of air. The faculties are transferred to space.
translation_text.dn2:23.4: Four men with a bier carry away the corpse.
translation_text.dn2:23.5: Their footprints show the way to the cremation ground.
translation_text.dn2:23.6: The bones become bleached. Offerings dedicated to the gods end in ashes.
translation_text.dn2:23.7: Giving is a doctrine of morons.
translation_text.dn2:23.8: When anyone affirms a positive teaching it’s just hollow, false nonsense.
translation_text.dn2:23.9: Both the foolish and the astute are annihilated and destroyed when their body breaks up, and don’t exist after death.’
translation_text.dn2:24.1: And so, when I asked Ajita of the hair blanket about the fruits of the ascetic life apparent in the present life, he answered with the doctrine of annihilationism.
translation_text.dn2:24.2: It was like someone who, when asked about a mango, answered with a breadfruit, or when asked about a breadfruit, answered with a mango.
translation_text.dn2:24.5: ‘How on earth could one such as I presume to rebuke an ascetic or brahmin living in my realm?’
translation_text.dn2:24.6: So I neither approved nor rejected that statement of Ajita of the hair blanket.
translation_text.dn2:24.7: I was displeased, but did not express my displeasure. Neither accepting what he said nor contradicting it, I got up from my seat and left.
translation_text.dn2:25.1: This one time, sir, I approached Pakudha Kaccāyana and exchanged greetings with him.
translation_text.dn2:25.2: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, I sat down to one side, and asked him the same question.
translation_text.dn2:26.2: ‘Great king, these seven substances are not made, not derived, not created, without a creator, barren, steady as a mountain peak, standing firm like a pillar.
translation_text.dn2:26.3: They don’t move or deteriorate or obstruct each other. They’re unable to cause pleasure, pain, or both pleasure and pain to each other.
translation_text.dn2:26.5: The substances of earth, water, fire, air; pleasure, pain, and the soul is the seventh.
translation_text.dn2:26.6: These seven substances are not made, not derived, not created, without a creator, barren, steady as a mountain peak, standing firm like a pillar.
translation_text.dn2:26.7: They don’t move or deteriorate or obstruct each other. They’re unable to cause pleasure, pain, or both pleasure and pain to each other.
translation_text.dn2:26.8: And here there is no-one who kills or who makes others kill; no-one who learns or who educates others; no-one who understands or who helps others understand.
translation_text.dn2:26.9: If you chop off someone’s head with a sharp sword, you don’t take anyone’s life.
translation_text.dn2:26.10: The sword simply passes through the gap between the seven substances.’
translation_text.dn2:27.1: And so, when I asked Pakudha Kaccāyana about the fruits of the ascetic life apparent in the present life, he answered with something else entirely.
translation_text.dn2:27.2: It was like someone who, when asked about a mango, answered with a breadfruit, or when asked about a breadfruit, answered with a mango.
translation_text.dn2:27.5: ‘How on earth could one such as I presume to rebuke an ascetic or brahmin living in my realm?’
translation_text.dn2:27.6: So I neither approved nor rejected that statement of Pakudha Kaccāyana.
translation_text.dn2:27.7: I was displeased, but did not express my displeasure. Neither accepting what he said nor contradicting it, I got up from my seat and left.
translation_text.dn2:28.0: 3.5. The Doctrine of the Jain Ascetic of the Ñātika Clan
translation_text.dn2:28.1: This one time, sir, I approached the Jain Ñātika and exchanged greetings with him.
translation_text.dn2:28.2: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, I sat down to one side, and asked him the same question.
translation_text.dn2:29.2: ‘Great king, consider a Jain ascetic who is restrained in the fourfold constraint.
translation_text.dn2:29.3: And how is a Jain ascetic restrained in the fourfold constraint?
translation_text.dn2:29.4: It’s when a Jain ascetic is restrained in all that is to be restrained, is bridled in all that is to be restrained, has shaken off evil in all that is to be restrained, and is curbed in all that is to be restrained.
translation_text.dn2:29.5: That’s how a Jain ascetic is restrained in the fourfold constraint.
translation_text.dn2:29.6: When a Jain ascetic is restrained in the fourfold constraint,
translation_text.dn2:29.7: they’re called a knotless one who is self-realized, self-controlled, and steadfast.’
translation_text.dn2:30.1: And so, when I asked the Jain Ñātika about the fruits of the ascetic life apparent in the present life, he answered with the fourfold constraint.
translation_text.dn2:30.2: It was like someone who, when asked about a mango, answered with a breadfruit, or when asked about a breadfruit, answered with a mango.
translation_text.dn2:30.5: ‘How on earth could one such as I presume to rebuke an ascetic or brahmin living in my realm?’
translation_text.dn2:30.6: So I neither approved nor rejected that statement of the Jain Ñātika.
translation_text.dn2:30.7: I was displeased, but did not express my displeasure. Neither accepting what he said nor contradicting it, I got up from my seat and left.
translation_text.dn2:31.1: This one time, sir, I approached Sañjaya Belaṭṭhiputta and exchanged greetings with him.
translation_text.dn2:31.2: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, I sat down to one side, and asked him the same question.
translation_text.dn2:32.2: ‘Suppose you were to ask me whether there is another world. If I believed that to be the case, I would say so.
translation_text.dn2:32.3: But I don’t say it’s like this. I don’t say it’s like that. I don’t say it’s otherwise. I don’t say it’s not so. And I don’t deny it’s not so.
translation_text.dn2:32.4: Suppose you were to ask me whether there is no other world …
translation_text.dn2:32.5: whether there both is and is not another world …
translation_text.dn2:32.6: whether there neither is nor is not another world …
translation_text.dn2:32.7: whether there are beings who are reborn spontaneously …
translation_text.dn2:32.8: whether there are no beings who are reborn spontaneously …
translation_text.dn2:32.9: whether there both are and are not beings who are reborn spontaneously …
translation_text.dn2:32.10: whether there neither are nor are not beings who are reborn spontaneously …
translation_text.dn2:32.11: whether there is fruit and result of good and bad deeds …
translation_text.dn2:32.12: whether there is no fruit and result of good and bad deeds …
translation_text.dn2:32.13: whether there both is and is not fruit and result of good and bad deeds …
translation_text.dn2:32.14: whether there neither is nor is not fruit and result of good and bad deeds …
translation_text.dn2:32.15: whether a realized one still exists after death …
translation_text.dn2:32.16: whether a realized one no longer exists after death …
translation_text.dn2:32.17: whether a realized one both still exists and no longer exists after death …
translation_text.dn2:32.18: whether a realized one neither exists nor doesn’t exist after death. If I believed that to be the case, I would say so.
translation_text.dn2:32.19: But I don’t say it’s like this. I don’t say it’s like that. I don’t say it’s otherwise. I don’t say it’s not so. And I don’t deny it’s not so.’
translation_text.dn2:33.1: And so, when I asked Sañjaya Belaṭṭhiputta about the fruits of the ascetic life apparent in the present life, he answered with flip-flopping.
translation_text.dn2:33.2: It was like someone who, when asked about a mango, answered with a breadfruit, or when asked about a breadfruit, answered with a mango.
translation_text.dn2:33.5: ‘This is the most foolish and stupid of all these ascetics and brahmins!
translation_text.dn2:33.6: How on earth can he answer with flip-flopping when asked about the fruits of the ascetic life apparent in the present life?’
translation_text.dn2:33.8: ‘How on earth could one such as I presume to rebuke an ascetic or brahmin living in my realm?’
translation_text.dn2:33.9: So I neither approved nor rejected that statement of Sañjaya Belaṭṭhiputta.
translation_text.dn2:33.10: I was displeased, but did not express my displeasure. Neither accepting what he said nor contradicting it, I got up from my seat and left.
translation_text.dn2:34.0.1: 4. The Fruits of the Ascetic Life
translation_text.dn2:34.0.2: 4.1. The First Fruit of the Ascetic Life
translation_text.dn2:34.1: And so I ask the Buddha:
translation_text.dn2:34.2: Sir, there are many different professional fields.
translation_text.dn2:34.3: These include elephant riders, cavalry, charioteers, archers, bannermen, adjutants, food servers, warrior-chiefs, princes, chargers, great warriors, heroes, leather-clad soldiers, and sons of bondservants.
translation_text.dn2:34.4: They also include bakers, barbers, bathroom attendants, cooks, garland-makers, dyers, embroiderers, basket-makers, potters, accountants, finger-talliers, or those following any similar professions. All these live off the fruits of their profession which are apparent in this very life.
translation_text.dn2:34.5: With that they make themselves happy and pleased. They make their parents, their children and partners, and their friends and colleagues happy and pleased. And they establish an uplifting religious donation for ascetics and brahmins that’s conducive to heaven, ripens in happiness, and leads to heaven.
translation_text.dn2:34.6: Sir, can you point out a fruit of the ascetic life that’s likewise apparent in this very life?”
translation_text.dn2:34.8: Well then, I’ll ask you about this in return, and you can answer as you like.
translation_text.dn2:35.1: What do you think, great king?
translation_text.dn2:35.2: Suppose you had a person who was a bondservant, a worker. They get up before you and go to bed after you, and are obliging, behaving nicely and speaking politely, and gazing up at your face.
translation_text.dn2:35.4: ‘The outcome and result of good deeds is just so incredible, so amazing!
translation_text.dn2:35.5: For this King Ajātasattu is a human being, and so am I.
translation_text.dn2:35.6: Yet he amuses himself, supplied and provided with the five kinds of sensual stimulation as if he were a god.
translation_text.dn2:35.7: Whereas I’m his bondservant, his worker. I get up before him and go to bed after him, and am obliging, behaving nicely and speaking politely, and gazing up at his face.
translation_text.dn2:35.8: I really should do good deeds.
translation_text.dn2:35.9: Why don’t I shave off my hair and beard, dress in ocher robes, and go forth from the lay life to homelessness?’
translation_text.dn2:35.10: After some time, that is what they do.
translation_text.dn2:35.11: Having gone forth they’d live restrained in body, speech, and mind, living content with nothing more than food and clothes, delighting in seclusion.
translation_text.dn2:35.12: And suppose your men were to report all this to you.
translation_text.dn2:35.17: ‘Bring that person to me! Let them once more be my bondservant, my worker’?”
translation_text.dn2:36.2: Rather, I would bow to them, rise in their presence, and offer them a seat. I’d invite them to accept robes, almsfood, lodgings, and medicines and supplies for the sick. And I’d organize their lawful guarding and protection.”
translation_text.dn2:36.4: If this is so, is there a fruit of the ascetic life apparent in the present life or not?”
translation_text.dn2:36.6: “This is the first fruit of the ascetic life that’s apparent in this very life, which I point out to you.”
translation_text.dn2:37.0: 4.2. The Second Fruit of the Ascetic Life
translation_text.dn2:37.1: “But sir, can you point out another fruit of the ascetic life that’s likewise apparent in this very life?”
translation_text.dn2:37.3: Well then, I’ll ask you about this in return, and you can answer as you like.
translation_text.dn2:37.4: What do you think, great king?
translation_text.dn2:37.5: Suppose you had a person who was a farmer, a householder, a hard worker, someone who builds up their capital.
translation_text.dn2:37.7: ‘The outcome and result of good deeds is just so incredible, so amazing!
translation_text.dn2:37.8: For this King Ajātasattu is a human being, and so am I.
translation_text.dn2:37.9: Yet he amuses himself, supplied and provided with the five kinds of sensual stimulation as if he were a god.
translation_text.dn2:37.10: Whereas I’m a farmer, a householder, a hard worker, someone who builds up their capital.
translation_text.dn2:37.11: I really should do good deeds.
translation_text.dn2:37.12: Why don’t I shave off my hair and beard, dress in ocher robes, and go forth from the lay life to homelessness?’
translation_text.dn2:37.13: After some time they give up a large or small fortune, and a large or small family circle. They’d shave off hair and beard, dress in ocher robes, and go forth from the lay life to homelessness.
translation_text.dn2:37.14: Having gone forth they’d live restrained in body, speech, and mind, living content with nothing more than food and clothes, delighting in seclusion.
translation_text.dn2:37.15: And suppose your men were to report all this to you.
translation_text.dn2:37.20: ‘Bring that person to me! Let them once more be a farmer, a householder, a hard worker, someone who builds up their capital’?”
translation_text.dn2:38.2: Rather, I would bow to them, rise in their presence, and offer them a seat. I’d invite them to accept robes, almsfood, lodgings, and medicines and supplies for the sick. And I’d organize their lawful guarding and protection.”
translation_text.dn2:38.4: If this is so, is there a fruit of the ascetic life apparent in the present life or not?”
translation_text.dn2:38.6: “This is the second fruit of the ascetic life that’s apparent in this very life, which I point out to you.”
translation_text.dn2:39.0: 4.3. The Finer Fruits of the Ascetic Life
translation_text.dn2:39.1: “But sir, can you point out a fruit of the ascetic life that’s apparent in this very life which is better and finer than these?”
translation_text.dn2:39.3: Well then, listen and apply your mind well, I will speak.”
translation_text.dn2:40.1: “Consider when a Realized One arises in the world, perfected, a fully awakened Buddha, accomplished in knowledge and conduct, holy, knower of the world, supreme guide for those fit for training, teacher of gods and humans, awakened, blessed.
translation_text.dn2:40.2: He has realized with his own insight this world—with its gods, Māras, and divinities, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, gods and humans—and he makes it known to others.
translation_text.dn2:40.3: He proclaims a teaching that is good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, meaningful and well-phrased. And he reveals a spiritual practice that’s entirely full and pure.
translation_text.dn2:41.1: A householder hears that teaching, or a householder’s child, or someone reborn in a good family.
translation_text.dn2:41.2: They gain faith in the Realized One
translation_text.dn2:41.4: ‘Life at home is cramped and dirty, life gone forth is wide open.
translation_text.dn2:41.5: It’s not easy for someone living at home to lead the spiritual life utterly full and pure, like a polished shell.
translation_text.dn2:41.6: Why don’t I shave off my hair and beard, dress in ocher robes, and go forth from the lay life to homelessness?’
translation_text.dn2:41.7: After some time they give up a large or small fortune, and a large or small family circle. They shave off hair and beard, dress in ocher robes, and go forth from the lay life to homelessness.
translation_text.dn2:42.1: Once they’ve gone forth, they live restrained in the monastic code, conducting themselves well and resorting for alms in suitable places. Seeing danger in the slightest fault, they keep the rules they’ve undertaken. They act skillfully by body and speech. They’re purified in livelihood and accomplished in ethical conduct. They guard the sense doors, have mindfulness and situational awareness, and are content.
translation_text.dn2:43.1: And how, great king, is a mendicant accomplished in ethics?
translation_text.dn2:43.2: It’s when a mendicant gives up killing living creatures, renouncing the rod and the sword. They’re scrupulous and kind, living full of sympathy for all living beings.
translation_text.dn2:43.4: They give up stealing. They take only what’s given, and expect only what’s given. They keep themselves clean by not thieving.
translation_text.dn2:43.6: They give up unchastity. They are chaste, set apart, avoiding the vulgar act of sex.
translation_text.dn2:44.1: They give up lying. They speak the truth and stick to the truth. They’re honest and dependable, and don’t trick the world with their words.
translation_text.dn2:44.3: They give up divisive speech. They don’t repeat in one place what they heard in another so as to divide people against each other. Instead, they reconcile those who are divided and support those who are united, delighting in harmony, loving harmony, speaking words that promote harmony.
translation_text.dn2:44.5: They give up harsh speech. They speak in a way that’s mellow, pleasing to the ear, lovely, going to the heart, polite, likable and agreeable to the people.
translation_text.dn2:44.7: They give up talking nonsense. Their words are timely, true, and meaningful, in line with the teaching and training. They say things at the right time which are valuable, reasonable, succinct, and beneficial.
translation_text.dn2:45.1: They refrain from injuring plants and seeds.
translation_text.dn2:45.2: They eat in one part of the day, abstaining from eating at night and food at the wrong time.
translation_text.dn2:45.3: They refrain from seeing shows of dancing, singing, and music .
translation_text.dn2:45.4: They refrain from attiring and adorning themselves with garlands, fragrance, and makeup.
translation_text.dn2:45.5: They refrain from high and luxurious beds.
translation_text.dn2:45.6: They refrain from receiving gold and currency,
translation_text.dn2:45.15: They refrain from running errands and messages;
translation_text.dn2:45.19: mutilation, murder, abduction, banditry, plunder, and violence.
translation_text.dn2:45.21: The shorter section on ethics is finished.
translation_text.dn2:46.1: There are some ascetics and brahmins who, while enjoying food given in faith, still engage in injuring plants and seeds.
translation_text.dn2:46.2: These include plants propagated from roots, stems, cuttings, or joints; and those from regular seeds as the fifth. They refrain from such injury to plants and seeds.
translation_text.dn2:47.1: There are some ascetics and brahmins who, while enjoying food given in faith, still engage in storing up goods for their own use.
translation_text.dn2:47.2: This includes such things as food, drink, clothes, vehicles, bedding, fragrance, and things of the flesh.
translation_text.dn2:47.3: They refrain from storing up such goods.
translation_text.dn2:48.1: There are some ascetics and brahmins who, while enjoying food given in faith, still engage in seeing shows.
translation_text.dn2:48.2: This includes such things as dancing, singing, music, performances, and storytelling; clapping, gongs, and kettledrums; beauty pageants; pole-acrobatics and bone-washing displays of the corpse-workers; battles of elephants, horses, buffaloes, bulls, goats, rams, chickens, and quails; staff-fights, boxing, and wrestling; combat, roll calls of the armed forces, battle-formations, and regimental reviews.
translation_text.dn2:49.1: There are some ascetics and brahmins who, while enjoying food given in faith, still engage in gambling that causes negligence.
translation_text.dn2:49.2: This includes such things as checkers with eight or ten rows, checkers in the air, hopscotch, spillikins, board-games, tip-cat, drawing straws, dice, leaf-flutes, toy plows, somersaults, pinwheels, toy measures, toy carts, toy bows, guessing words from syllables, guessing another’s thoughts, and imitating musical instruments.
translation_text.dn2:50.1: There are some ascetics and brahmins who, while enjoying food given in faith, still make use of high and luxurious bedding.
translation_text.dn2:50.2: This includes such things as sofas, couches, woolen covers—shag-piled, colorful, white, embroidered with flowers, quilted, embroidered with animals, double-or single-fringed—and silk covers studded with gems, as well as silken sheets, woven carpets, rugs for elephants, horses, or chariots, antelope hide rugs, and spreads of fine deer hide, with a canopy above and red cushions at both ends.
translation_text.dn2:51.1: There are some ascetics and brahmins who, while enjoying food given in faith, still engage in attiring and adorning themselves with garlands, fragrance, and makeup.
translation_text.dn2:51.2: This includes such things as applying beauty products by anointing, massaging, bathing, and rubbing; mirrors, ointments, garlands, fragrances, and makeup; face-powder, foundation, bracelets, headbands, fancy walking-sticks or containers, rapiers, parasols, fancy sandals, turbans, jewelry, chowries, and long-fringed white robes.
translation_text.dn2:51.3: They refrain from such attirement and adornment.
translation_text.dn2:52.1: There are some ascetics and brahmins who, while enjoying food given in faith, still engage in low talk.
translation_text.dn2:52.2: This includes such topics as talk about kings, bandits, and ministers; talk about armies, threats, and wars; talk about food, drink, clothes, and beds; talk about garlands and fragrances; talk about family, vehicles, villages, towns, cities, and countries; talk about women and heroes; street talk and well talk; talk about the departed; motley talk; tales of land and sea; and talk about being reborn in this or that place.
translation_text.dn2:52.3: They refrain from such low talk.
translation_text.dn2:53.1: There are some ascetics and brahmins who, while enjoying food given in faith, still engage in arguments.
translation_text.dn2:53.2: They say such things as: ‘You don’t understand this teaching and training. I understand this teaching and training. What, you understand this teaching and training? You’re practicing wrong. I’m practicing right. I stay on topic, you don’t. You said last what you should have said first. You said first what you should have said last. What you’ve thought so much about has been disproved. Your doctrine is refuted. Go on, save your doctrine! You’re trapped; get yourself out of this—if you can!’
translation_text.dn2:53.3: They refrain from such argumentative talk.
translation_text.dn2:54.1: There are some ascetics and brahmins who, while enjoying food given in faith, still engage in running errands and messages.
translation_text.dn2:54.2: This includes running errands for rulers, ministers, aristocrats, brahmins, householders, or princes who say: ‘Go here, go there. Take this, bring that from there.’
translation_text.dn2:55.1: There are some ascetics and brahmins who, while enjoying food given in faith, still engage in fawning, flattery, hinting, and belittling, and using material things to chase after other material things. They refrain from such fraud and flattery.
translation_text.dn2:55.3: The middle section on ethics is finished.
translation_text.dn2:56.1: There are some ascetics and brahmins who, while enjoying food given in faith, still earn a living by low lore, by wrong livelihood.
translation_text.dn2:56.2: This includes such fields as augury, omenology, divining portents, interpreting dreams, divining features of men and women, divining holes in cloth gnawed by mice, fire offerings, ladle offerings, offerings of husks, rice powder, rice, ghee, or oil; offerings from the mouth, blood sacrifices, limb-reading; geomancy for building sites, fields, and cemeteries; exorcisms, earth magic, snake charming, poisons; the lore of the scorpion, the rat, the bird, and the crow; prophesying life span, chanting for protection, and divining omens from wild animals.
translation_text.dn2:56.3: They refrain from such low lore, such wrong livelihood.
translation_text.dn2:57.1: There are some ascetics and brahmins who, while enjoying food given in faith, still earn a living by low lore, by wrong livelihood.
translation_text.dn2:57.2: This includes reading the marks of gems, cloth, clubs, swords, spears, arrows, bows, weapons, women, men, boys, girls, male and female bondservants, elephants, horses, buffaloes, bulls, cows, goats, rams, chickens, quails, monitor lizards, rabbits, tortoises, or deer.
translation_text.dn2:57.3: They refrain from such low lore, such wrong livelihood.
translation_text.dn2:58.1: There are some ascetics and brahmins who, while enjoying food given in faith, still earn a living by low lore, by wrong livelihood.
translation_text.dn2:58.2: This includes making predictions that the king will march forth or march back; or that our king will attack and the enemy king will retreat, or vice versa; or that our king will triumph and the enemy king will be defeated, or vice versa; and so there will be victory for one and defeat for the other.
translation_text.dn2:58.3: They refrain from such low lore, such wrong livelihood.
translation_text.dn2:59.1: There are some ascetics and brahmins who, while enjoying food given in faith, still earn a living by low lore, by wrong livelihood.
translation_text.dn2:59.2: This includes making predictions that there will be an eclipse of the moon, or sun, or stars; that the sun, moon, and stars will be in conjunction or in opposition; that there will be a meteor shower, a fiery horizon, an earthquake, or thunder in the heavens; that there will be a rising, a setting, a darkening, a brightening of the moon, sun, and stars. And it also includes making predictions about the results of all such phenomena.
translation_text.dn2:59.3: They refrain from such low lore, such wrong livelihood.
translation_text.dn2:60.1: There are some ascetics and brahmins who, while enjoying food given in faith, still earn a living by low lore, by wrong livelihood.
translation_text.dn2:60.2: This includes predicting whether there will be plenty of rain or drought; plenty to eat or famine; an abundant harvest or a bad harvest; security or peril; sickness or health. It also includes such occupations as arithmetic, accounting, calculating, poetry, and cosmology.
translation_text.dn2:60.3: They refrain from such low lore, such wrong livelihood.
translation_text.dn2:61.1: There are some ascetics and brahmins who, while enjoying food given in faith, still earn a living by low lore, by wrong livelihood.
translation_text.dn2:61.2: This includes making arrangements for giving and taking in marriage; for engagement and divorce; and for scattering rice inwards or outwards at the wedding ceremony. It also includes casting spells for good or bad luck, treating impacted fetuses, binding the tongue, or locking the jaws; charms for the hands and ears; questioning a mirror, a girl, or a god as an oracle; worshiping the sun, worshiping the Great One, breathing fire, and invoking Siri, the goddess of luck.
translation_text.dn2:61.3: They refrain from such low lore, such wrong livelihood.
translation_text.dn2:62.1: There are some ascetics and brahmins who, while enjoying food given in faith, still earn a living by low lore, by wrong livelihood.
translation_text.dn2:62.2: This includes rites for propitiation, for granting wishes, for ghosts, for the earth, for rain, for property settlement, and for preparing and consecrating house sites, and rites involving sipping water and bathing, and oblations. It also includes administering emetics, purgatives, expectorants, and phlegmagogues; administering ear-oils, eye restoratives, nasal medicine, ointments, and counter-ointments; surgery with needle and scalpel, treating children, prescribing root medicines, and herbal bandages.
translation_text.dn2:62.3: They refrain from such low lore, such wrong livelihood.
translation_text.dn2:63.1: A mendicant thus accomplished in ethics sees no danger in any quarter in regards to their ethical restraint.
translation_text.dn2:63.2: It’s like a king who has defeated his enemies. He sees no danger from his foes in any quarter.
translation_text.dn2:63.3: In the same way, a mendicant thus accomplished in ethics sees no danger in any quarter in regards to their ethical restraint.
translation_text.dn2:63.4: When they have this entire spectrum of noble ethics, they experience a blameless happiness inside themselves.
translation_text.dn2:63.5: That’s how a mendicant is accomplished in ethics.
translation_text.dn2:63.6: The longer section on ethics is finished.
translation_text.dn2:64.1: And how does a mendicant guard the sense doors?
translation_text.dn2:64.2: When a mendicant sees a sight with their eyes, they don’t get caught up in the features and details.
translation_text.dn2:64.3: If the faculty of sight were left unrestrained, bad unskillful qualities of covetousness and displeasure would become overwhelming. For this reason, they practice restraint, protecting the faculty of sight, and achieving its restraint.
translation_text.dn2:64.4: When they hear a sound with their ears …
translation_text.dn2:64.5: When they smell an odor with their nose …
translation_text.dn2:64.6: When they taste a flavor with their tongue …
translation_text.dn2:64.7: When they feel a touch with their body …
translation_text.dn2:64.8: When they know an idea with their mind, they don’t get caught up in the features and details.
translation_text.dn2:64.9: If the faculty of mind were left unrestrained, bad unskillful qualities of covetousness and displeasure would become overwhelming. For this reason, they practice restraint, protecting the faculty of mind, and achieving its restraint.
translation_text.dn2:64.10: When they have this noble sense restraint, they experience an unsullied bliss inside themselves.
translation_text.dn2:64.11: That’s how a mendicant guards the sense doors.
translation_text.dn2:65.1: And how does a mendicant have mindfulness and situational awareness?
translation_text.dn2:65.2: It’s when a mendicant acts with situational awareness when going out and coming back; when looking ahead and aside; when bending and extending the limbs; when bearing the outer robe, bowl and robes; when eating, drinking, chewing, and tasting; when urinating and defecating; when walking, standing, sitting, sleeping, waking, speaking, and keeping silent.
translation_text.dn2:65.3: That’s how a mendicant has mindfulness and situational awareness.
translation_text.dn2:66.1: And how is a mendicant content?
translation_text.dn2:66.2: It’s when a mendicant is content with robes to look after the body and almsfood to look after the belly. Wherever they go, they set out taking only these things.
translation_text.dn2:66.3: They’re like a bird: wherever it flies, wings are its only burden.
translation_text.dn2:66.4: In the same way, a mendicant is content with robes to look after the body and almsfood to look after the belly. Wherever they go, they set out taking only these things.
translation_text.dn2:66.5: That’s how a mendicant is content.
translation_text.dn2:67.1: When they have this entire spectrum of noble ethics, this noble sense restraint, this noble mindfulness and situational awareness, and this noble contentment,
translation_text.dn2:67.2: they frequent a secluded lodging—a wilderness, the root of a tree, a hill, a ravine, a mountain cave, a charnel ground, a forest, the open air, a heap of straw.
translation_text.dn2:67.3: After the meal, they return from almsround, sit down cross-legged, set their body straight, and establish mindfulness in their presence.
translation_text.dn2:68.1: Giving up covetousness for the world, they meditate with a heart rid of covetousness, cleansing the mind of covetousness.
translation_text.dn2:68.2: Giving up ill will and malevolence, they meditate with a mind rid of ill will, full of sympathy for all living beings, cleansing the mind of ill will.
translation_text.dn2:68.3: Giving up dullness and drowsiness, they meditate with a mind rid of dullness and drowsiness, perceiving light, mindful and aware, cleansing the mind of dullness and drowsiness.
translation_text.dn2:68.4: Giving up restlessness and remorse, they meditate without restlessness, their mind peaceful inside, cleansing the mind of restlessness and remorse.
translation_text.dn2:68.5: Giving up doubt, they meditate having gone beyond doubt, not undecided about skillful qualities, cleansing the mind of doubt.
translation_text.dn2:69.1: Suppose a man who has gotten into debt were to apply himself to work,
translation_text.dn2:69.3: He would pay off the original loan and have enough left over to support his partner.
translation_text.dn2:69.8: he’d be filled with joy and happiness.
translation_text.dn2:70.1: Suppose there was a person who was sick, suffering, gravely ill. They’d lose their appetite and get physically weak.
translation_text.dn2:70.2: But after some time they’d recover from that illness, and regain their appetite and their strength.
translation_text.dn2:70.8: they’d be filled with joy and happiness.
translation_text.dn2:71.1: Suppose a person was imprisoned in a jail.
translation_text.dn2:71.2: But after some time they were released from jail, safe and sound, with no loss of wealth.
translation_text.dn2:71.6: they’d be filled with joy and happiness.
translation_text.dn2:72.1: Suppose a person was a bondservant. They would not be their own master, but indentured to another, unable to go where they wish.
translation_text.dn2:72.2: But after some time they’d be freed from servitude. They would be their own master, not indentured to another, a freeman able to go where they wish.
translation_text.dn2:72.6: they’d be filled with joy and happiness.
translation_text.dn2:73.1: Suppose there was a person with wealth and property who was traveling along a desert road, which was perilous, with nothing to eat.
translation_text.dn2:73.2: But after some time they crossed over the desert safely, arriving within a village, a sanctuary free of peril.
translation_text.dn2:73.6: they’d be filled with joy and happiness.
translation_text.dn2:74.1: In the same way, as long as these five hindrances are not given up inside themselves, a mendicant regards them thus as a debt, a disease, a prison, slavery, and a desert crossing.
translation_text.dn2:74.2: But when these five hindrances are given up inside themselves, a mendicant regards this as freedom from debt, good health, release from prison, emancipation, and a place of sanctuary at last.
translation_text.dn2:74.4: Seeing that the hindrances have been given up in them, joy springs up. Being joyful, rapture springs up. When the mind is full of rapture, the body becomes tranquil. When the body is tranquil, they feel bliss. And when blissful, the mind becomes immersed.
translation_text.dn2:75.1: Quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, they enter and remain in the first absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of seclusion, while placing the mind and keeping it connected.
translation_text.dn2:75.2: They drench, steep, fill, and spread their body with rapture and bliss born of seclusion. There’s no part of the body that’s not spread with rapture and bliss born of seclusion.
translation_text.dn2:76.1: It’s like when a deft bathroom attendant or their apprentice pours bath powder into a bronze dish, sprinkling it little by little with water. They knead it until the ball of bath powder is soaked and saturated with moisture, spread through inside and out; yet no moisture oozes out.
translation_text.dn2:76.2: In the same way, a mendicant drenches, steeps, fills, and spreads their body with rapture and bliss born of seclusion. There’s no part of the body that’s not spread with rapture and bliss born of seclusion.
translation_text.dn2:76.3: This, great king, is a fruit of the ascetic life that’s apparent in the present life which is better and finer than the former ones.
translation_text.dn2:77.1: Furthermore, as the placing of the mind and keeping it connected are stilled, a mendicant enters and remains in the second absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of immersion, with internal clarity and mind at one, without applying the mind and keeping it connected.
translation_text.dn2:77.2: They drench, steep, fill, and spread their body with rapture and bliss born of immersion. There’s no part of the body that’s not spread with rapture and bliss born of immersion.
translation_text.dn2:78.1: It’s like a deep lake fed by spring water. There’s no inlet to the east, west, north, or south, and the heavens would not properly bestow showers from time to time.
translation_text.dn2:78.2: But the stream of cool water welling up in the lake drenches, steeps, fills, and spreads throughout the lake. There’s no part of the lake that’s not spread through with cool water.
translation_text.dn2:78.3: In the same way, a mendicant drenches, steeps, fills, and spreads their body with rapture and bliss born of immersion. There’s no part of the body that’s not spread with rapture and bliss born of immersion.
translation_text.dn2:78.4: This too, great king, is a fruit of the ascetic life that’s apparent in the present life which is better and finer than the former ones.
translation_text.dn2:79.1: Furthermore, with the fading away of rapture, a mendicant enters and remains in the third absorption, where they meditate with equanimity, mindful and aware, personally experiencing the bliss of which the noble ones declare, ‘Equanimous and mindful, one meditates in bliss.’
translation_text.dn2:79.2: They drench, steep, fill, and spread their body with bliss free of rapture. There’s no part of the body that’s not spread with bliss free of rapture.
translation_text.dn2:80.1: It’s like a pool with blue water lilies, or pink or white lotuses. Some of them sprout and grow in the water without rising above it, thriving underwater. From the tip to the root they’re drenched, steeped, filled, and soaked with cool water. There’s no part of them that’s not soaked with cool water.
translation_text.dn2:80.2: In the same way, a mendicant drenches, steeps, fills, and spreads their body with bliss free of rapture. There’s no part of the body that’s not spread with bliss free of rapture.
translation_text.dn2:80.3: This too, great king, is a fruit of the ascetic life that’s apparent in the present life which is better and finer than the former ones.
translation_text.dn2:81.1: Furthermore, with the giving up of pleasure and pain and the disappearance of former happiness and sadness, a mendicant enters and remains in the fourth absorption, without pleasure or pain, with pure equanimity and mindfulness.
translation_text.dn2:81.2: They sit spreading their body through with pure bright mind. There’s no part of the body that’s not spread with pure bright mind.
translation_text.dn2:82.1: It’s like someone sitting wrapped from head to foot with white cloth. There’s no part of the body that’s not spread over with white cloth.
translation_text.dn2:82.2: In the same way, they sit spreading their body through with pure bright mind. There’s no part of the body that’s not spread with pure bright mind.
translation_text.dn2:82.3: This too, great king, is a fruit of the ascetic life that’s apparent in the present life which is better and finer than the former ones.
translation_text.dn2:83.1: When their mind has become immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—they project it and extend it toward knowledge and vision.
translation_text.dn2:83.3: ‘This body of mine is formed. It’s made up of the four principal states, produced by mother and father, built up from rice and porridge, liable to impermanence, to wearing away and erosion, to breaking up and destruction.
translation_text.dn2:83.4: And this consciousness of mine is attached to it, tied to it.’
translation_text.dn2:84.1: Suppose there was a beryl gem that was naturally lustrous, eight-faceted, well-worked, transparent, clear, and unclouded, endowed with all good qualities.
translation_text.dn2:84.2: And it was strung with a thread of blue, yellow, red, white, or golden brown.
translation_text.dn2:84.3: And a person with clear eyes were to take it in their hand and check it:
translation_text.dn2:84.4: ‘This beryl gem is naturally lustrous, eight-faceted, well-worked, transparent, clear, and unclouded, endowed with all good qualities.
translation_text.dn2:84.5: And it’s strung with a thread of blue, yellow, red, white, or golden brown.’
translation_text.dn2:84.6: In the same way, when their mind has become immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—they project it and extend it toward knowledge and vision.
translation_text.dn2:84.10: This too, great king, is a fruit of the ascetic life that’s apparent in the present life which is better and finer than the former ones.
translation_text.dn2:85.1: When their mind has become immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—they project it and extend it toward the creation of a mind-made body.
translation_text.dn2:85.2: From this body they create another body—formed, mind-made, whole in its major and minor limbs, not deficient in any faculty.
translation_text.dn2:86.1: Suppose a person was to draw a reed out from its sheath.
translation_text.dn2:86.3: ‘This is the reed, this is the sheath. The reed and the sheath are different things. The reed has been drawn out from the sheath.’
translation_text.dn2:86.4: Or suppose a person was to draw a sword out from its scabbard.
translation_text.dn2:86.6: ‘This is the sword, this is the scabbard. The sword and the scabbard are different things. The sword has been drawn out from the scabbard.’
translation_text.dn2:86.7: Or suppose a person was to draw a snake out from its slough.
translation_text.dn2:86.9: ‘This is the snake, this is the slough. The snake and the slough are different things. The snake has been drawn out from the slough.’
translation_text.dn2:86.10: In the same way, when their mind has become immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—they project it and extend it toward the creation of a mind-made body.
translation_text.dn2:86.11: From this body they create another body—formed, mind-made, whole in its major and minor limbs, not deficient in any faculty.
translation_text.dn2:86.12: This too, great king, is a fruit of the ascetic life that’s apparent in the present life which is better and finer than the former ones.
translation_text.dn2:87.1: When their mind has become immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—they project it and extend it toward psychic power.
translation_text.dn2:87.2: They wield the many kinds of psychic power: multiplying themselves and becoming one again; materializing and dematerializing; going unobstructed through a wall, a rampart, or a mountain as if through space; diving in and out of the earth as if it were water; walking on water as if it were earth; flying cross-legged through the sky like a bird; touching and stroking with the hand the sun and moon, so mighty and powerful; controlling the body as far as the realm of divinity.
translation_text.dn2:88.1: Suppose a deft potter or their apprentice had some well-prepared clay. They could produce any kind of pot that they like.
translation_text.dn2:88.2: Or suppose a deft ivory-carver or their apprentice had some well-prepared ivory. They could produce any kind of ivory item that they like.
translation_text.dn2:88.3: Or suppose a deft goldsmith or their apprentice had some well-prepared gold. They could produce any kind of gold item that they like.
translation_text.dn2:88.4: In the same way, when their mind has become immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—they project it and extend it toward psychic power.
translation_text.dn2:88.6: This too, great king, is a fruit of the ascetic life that’s apparent in the present life which is better and finer than the former ones.
translation_text.dn2:89.1: When their mind has become immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—they project it and extend it toward clairaudience.
translation_text.dn2:89.2: With clairaudience that is purified and superhuman, they hear both kinds of sounds, human and heavenly, whether near or far.
translation_text.dn2:90.1: Suppose there was a person traveling along the road. They’d hear the sound of drums, clay drums, horns, kettledrums, and tom-toms. They’d think: ‘That’s the sound of drums,’ and ‘that’s the sound of clay drums,’ and ‘that’s the sound of horns, kettledrums, and tom-toms.’
translation_text.dn2:90.2: In the same way, when their mind has become immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—they project it and extend it toward clairaudience.
translation_text.dn2:90.3: With clairaudience that is purified and superhuman, they hear both kinds of sounds, human and heavenly, whether near or far.
translation_text.dn2:90.4: This too, great king, is a fruit of the ascetic life that’s apparent in the present life which is better and finer than the former ones.
translation_text.dn2:91.1: When their mind has become immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—they project it and extend it toward encompassing the minds of others.
translation_text.dn2:91.2: They understand the minds of other beings and individuals, having encompassed them with their own mind.
translation_text.dn2:91.3: They understand mind with greed as ‘mind with greed’,
translation_text.dn2:91.4: and mind without greed as ‘mind without greed’.
translation_text.dn2:91.18: They understand unfreed mind as ‘unfreed mind’.
translation_text.dn2:92.1: Suppose there was a woman or man who was young, youthful, and fond of adornments, and they check their own reflection in a clean bright mirror or a clear bowl of water. If they had a spot they’d know ‘I have a spot,’ and if they had no spots they’d know ‘I have no spots.’
translation_text.dn2:92.2: In the same way, when their mind has become immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—they project it and extend it toward encompassing the minds of others.
translation_text.dn2:92.3: They understand the minds of other beings and individuals, having encompassed them with their own mind.
translation_text.dn2:92.20: This too, great king, is a fruit of the ascetic life that’s apparent in the present life which is better and finer than the former ones.
translation_text.dn2:93.1: When their mind has become immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—they project it and extend it toward recollection of past lives.
translation_text.dn2:93.2: They recollect many kinds of past lives, that is, one, two, three, four, five, ten, twenty, thirty, forty, fifty, a hundred, a thousand, a hundred thousand rebirths; many eons of the world contracting, many eons of the world expanding, many eons of the world contracting and expanding. They remember: ‘There, I was named this, my clan was that, I looked like this, and that was my food. This was how I felt pleasure and pain, and that was how my life ended. When I passed away from that place I was reborn somewhere else. There, too, I was named this, my clan was that, I looked like this, and that was my food. This was how I felt pleasure and pain, and that was how my life ended. When I passed away from that place I was reborn here.’ And so they recollect their many kinds of past lives, with features and details.
translation_text.dn2:94.1: Suppose a person was to leave their home village and go to another village. From that village they’d go to yet another village. And from that village they’d return to their home village. They’d think: ‘I went from my home village to another village. There I stood like this, sat like that, spoke like this, or kept silent like that. From that village I went to yet another village. There too I stood like this, sat like that, spoke like this, or kept silent like that. And from that village I returned to my home village.’
translation_text.dn2:94.2: In the same way, when their mind has become immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—they project it and extend it toward recollection of past lives.
translation_text.dn2:94.4: This too, great king, is a fruit of the ascetic life that’s apparent in the present life which is better and finer than the former ones.
translation_text.dn2:95.1: When their mind has become immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—they project it and extend it toward knowledge of the death and rebirth of sentient beings.
translation_text.dn2:95.2: With clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman, they see sentient beings passing away and being reborn—inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, in a good place or a bad place. They understand how sentient beings pass on according to their deeds: ‘These dear beings did bad things by way of body, speech, and mind. They denounced the noble ones; they had wrong view; and they chose to act out of that wrong view. When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell. These dear beings, however, did good things by way of body, speech, and mind. They never denounced the noble ones; they had right view; and they chose to act out of that right view. When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.’ And so, with clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman, they see sentient beings passing away and being reborn—inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, in a good place or a bad place. They understand how sentient beings pass on according to their deeds.
translation_text.dn2:96.1: Suppose there was a stilt longhouse at the central square. A person with clear eyes standing there might see humans entering and leaving a house, walking along the streets and paths, and sitting at the central square. They’d think: ‘These are people entering and leaving a house, walking along the streets and paths, and sitting at the central square.’
translation_text.dn2:96.2: In the same way, when their mind has become immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—they project it and extend it toward knowledge of the death and rebirth of sentient beings.
translation_text.dn2:96.4: This too, great king, is a fruit of the ascetic life that’s apparent in the present life which is better and finer than the former ones.
translation_text.dn2:97.1: When their mind has become immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—they project it and extend it toward knowledge of the ending of defilements.
translation_text.dn2:97.2: They truly understand: ‘This is suffering’ … ‘This is the origin of suffering’ … ‘This is the cessation of suffering’ … ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering’.
translation_text.dn2:97.3: They truly understand: ‘These are defilements’ … ‘This is the origin of defilements’ … ‘This is the cessation of defilements’ … ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of defilements’.
translation_text.dn2:97.4: Knowing and seeing like this, their mind is freed from the defilements of sensuality, desire to be reborn, and ignorance.
translation_text.dn2:97.5: When they’re freed, they know they’re freed.
translation_text.dn2:97.6: They understand: ‘Rebirth is ended, the spiritual journey has been completed, what had to be done has been done, there is nothing further for this place.’
translation_text.dn2:98.1: Suppose that in a mountain glen there was a lake that was transparent, clear, and unclouded. A person with clear eyes standing on the bank would see the clams and mussels, and pebbles and gravel, and schools of fish swimming about or staying still. They’d think: ‘This lake is transparent, clear, and unclouded. And here are the clams and mussels, and pebbles and gravel, and schools of fish swimming about or staying still.’
translation_text.dn2:98.2: In the same way, when their mind has become immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—they project it and extend it toward knowledge of the ending of defilements.
translation_text.dn2:98.8: This too, great king, is a fruit of the ascetic life that’s apparent in the present life which is better and finer than the former ones.
translation_text.dn2:98.9: And, great king, there is no other fruit of the ascetic life apparent in the present life which is better and finer than this.”
translation_text.dn2:99.0: 5. Ajātasattu Declares Himself a Lay Follower
translation_text.dn2:99.1: When the Buddha had spoken, King Ajātasattu said to him,
translation_text.dn2:99.3: As if he were righting the overturned, or revealing the hidden, or pointing out the path to the lost, or lighting a lamp in the dark so people with clear eyes can see what’s there, the Buddha has made the teaching clear in many ways.
translation_text.dn2:99.4: I go for refuge to the Buddha, to the teaching, and to the mendicant Saṅgha.
translation_text.dn2:99.5: From this day forth, may the Buddha remember me as a lay follower who has gone for refuge for life.
translation_text.dn2:99.6: I made a mistake, sir. It was foolish, stupid, and unskillful of me to take the life of my father, a just and principled king, for the sake of authority.
translation_text.dn2:99.7: Please, sir, accept my mistake for what it is, so I will restrain myself in future.”
translation_text.dn2:100.1: “Indeed, great king, you made a mistake. It was foolish, stupid, and unskillful of you to take the life of your father, a just and principled king, for the sake of sovereignty.
translation_text.dn2:100.2: But since you have recognized your mistake for what it is, and have dealt with it properly, I accept it.
translation_text.dn2:100.3: For it is growth in the training of the Noble One to recognize a mistake for what it is, deal with it properly, and commit to restraint in the future.”
translation_text.dn2:101.1: When the Buddha had spoken, King Ajātasattu said to him,
translation_text.dn2:101.2: “Well, now, sir, I must go. I have many duties, and much to do.”
translation_text.dn2:101.3: “Please, great king, go at your convenience.”
translation_text.dn2:101.4: Then the king, having approved and agreed with what the Buddha said, got up from his seat, bowed, and respectfully circled him, keeping him on his right, before leaving.
translation_text.dn2:102.1: Soon after the king had left, the Buddha addressed the mendicants,
translation_text.dn2:102.4: If he had not taken the life of his father, a just and principled king, the stainless, immaculate vision of the Dhamma would have arisen in him in that very seat.”
translation_text.dn2:102.5: That is what the Buddha said.
translation_text.dn2:102.6: Satisfied, the mendicants approved what the Buddha said.
